awd_titl_txt: SRN: Integrated Urban Infrastructure Solutions for Environmentally Sustainable, Healthy and Livable Cities.
awd_abstract_narration:
1444745 (Ramaswami)

Several hundred cities in the US and abroad, including 40 of the world's most populous cities (the C40 cities) have announced goals that include environmental sustainability, health, climate-resiliency and livability. Engineered infrastructures - defined broadly to include the seven key sectors that provide water, energy, food, sanitation/waste management, transportation (connectivity and access) and public spaces to more than half the world's people living in cities today - are essential in achieving these multi-faceted societal goals. Increasingly, cities are exploring the proposition that movement from large centralized systems toward local or distributed infrastructure, combined with changes in user-behavior and corresponding changes in institutions and policy in all the above sectors - is a critical pathway in achieving the triple goals of environment, health and livability (EHL goals). However, this proposition has never been verified on the ground due to three key gaps in the science of developing EHL focused cities, namely: (i) lack of standard metrics for monitoring EHL urban outcomes; (ii) lack of understanding of the role of social actors - across multiple scales from the household to city/ regional government - in the adoption and stewardship of distributed infrastructure solutions, and (iii) lack of dynamic urban models that can represent the EHL outcomes associated with distributed infrastructure systems and explore city futures. This SRN will bring together a network of universities, cities and industry partners who, jointly, will co-develop the science of sustainability, practical knowledge and policy innovations that will enable urban infrastructure transformation toward environmentally-sustainable, healthy and livable (EHL) cities. 

Three primary research thrusts will support this transformation of urban infrastructure. Theme 1 of the SRN will develop the science of integrated measurement of environmental sustainability, health and livability (EHL), capturing linkages, synergies and trade-offs, considering human-environment interactions with all the seven infrastructure sectors together. Theme 2 of the SRN will develop new principles for designing integrated social-infrastructural solutions, with engineering and social science fully assimilated across home-, neighborhood- and city-regional scales, drawing upon innovative field experiments underway in the SRN cities (7 U.S. and 4 Asian) linked with test beds in SRN research labs. Finally, Theme 3 will operationalize the new knowledge created in Themes 1 and 2, to describe the dynamic interactions between natural systems, urban design, infrastructures and people in a democratized simulation environment, which expands upon a platform used by cities across the globe to allow multiple stakeholders to explore city futures with distributed infrastructure scenarios based. The SRN will focus on linking research and education with concrete actions in SRN partner cities. By closely working with community, government and industry collaborators, the SRN will operationalize the Network's findings well beyond a research setting, enabling real-world impact. The SRN's focus on the role of distributed infrastructure in urban sustainability and the large data base the SRN will develop as part of the Theme 2 will pave the way for future research endeavors in urban sustainability. Among the SRN's outreach, training and education foci are: (i) training of Public Officials on design and implementation of coupled social-infrastructural solution through collaborations with our partner cities, and nationally- the National League of Cities, City Managers Association; (ii) a Summer REU program that engages Native Indian Students from a network of 6 Tribal Colleges - from the undergraduate level to graduate degrees, and (iii) an innovative interdisciplinary summer school on Integrated Infrastructure Solutions for Sustainable, Healthy and Livable Cities- for students at all 9 SRN Universities, connecting environmental sciences, infrastructure engineering, urban planning, social sciences, public affairs, and public health.

por.por_cntn:
A. MISSION: The overarching mission of the Sustainable Healthy Cities Network (SHCN) is to advance environmental sustainability (E), health (H), wellbeing (W), and livability (L) in diverse cities around the world, through innovations in infrastructure design, technology, policy, and social institutions. Our infrastructure sectors cover energy, water/wastewater, transportation, green infrastructure, and food systems. We develop science to understand how distributed infrastructure solutions, and the associated enabling technologies and policies, in energy, transportation, water/wastewater management, food, and green space can be designed to improve EHWL outcomes in diverse city types.

B. Project Outputs and Outcomes: Over the entire SHCN period, the following major accomplishments were achieved organized into intellectual merit and broader impacts.

B.1. INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

We report advances in systems science, overarching concepts, and specific sectoral models relating infrastructure to EHWL outcomes.

(1)   Urban System Science: Our research advances a social-ecological-infrastructural urban systems (SEIUS) framework that address complex linkages across multiple infrastructure and food systems sectors and EHWL outcomes, spanning spatial scales and connecting biophysical and social systems. The framework seeks to understand/model the influence of infrastructure design and policy on EHWL outcomes in a changing environment (with scarcity, extremes, population). Key publications articulating this framework have been published in Science and Nature Sustainability, and have provided the foundation for articulating the concept of sustainable urban systems, adopted by practitioners and policymakers such as the UN Environmental Programme (UNEP). 

 (2)   Developing Overarching Concepts and Methods:

a)      Environmental Footprinting: Conceptualized and developed transboundary communitywide infrastructure supply chain footprinting addressing multiple environmental impacts, e.g., carbon, energy, land, and water footprints, demonstrated for cities in the US and India.

b)     Infrastructure Correlates of Subjective Wellbeing: Developed novel methods for measuring subjective wellbeing, unpacking the role of infrastructure and food systems.

c)      Health Effects Modeling of Infrastructure Transitions: Modeled health effects of mobility transitions to electric vehicles, and waste-to-value interventions.

d)     Livability and Subjective Wellbeing: Literature review and conceptualization of the linkage between livability and subjective wellbeing.

e)      Inequality and Equity: Early development of a conceptual and data framework to operationalize measurement of inequality to inform equitable policies in urban systems. (Equity was outside the scope of the original proposal but became an element in response to research needs expressed by SHCN city partners.)

f)       Policy and Governance: Understanding behavioral interventions and governance of water and energy systems.

g)      Overarching Conceptual Framework for Urban Decarbonization Integrating Sectors and Scale.

 (3)   Sectoral Applications:

a)      Mobility: City case studies and USA-wide Shared Autonomous Electric Vehicles and Electric Vehicles deployment modeling, respectively.

b)     Energy: Measuring energy use at fine spatial scales in cities and developing methods to evaluate residential heating to electrically-driven heat pumps transitions.

c)      Green Infrastructure: A multi-objective design of green infrastructure systems.

d)     Food Systems: Assessing the potential for local food production to meet local demand; developing methods to characterize urban agriculture at the household and community level; measuring subjective wellbeing benefits of household gardening.

e)      Wastewater and Waste Sectors: Modeling resource recovery and its environmental and health co-benefits.

(4)   Disciplinary and Interdisciplinary Impacts: SHCN research advanced an overarching interdisciplinary Sustainability Science with key publications (e.g., in Nature Sustainability; Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences), as well as disciplinary advances and related publications in Engineering (e.g., Applied Energy), Environmental Science and Engineering (e.g., Environmental Science, & Technology), Public Health (e.g., Public Health Reviews), and Social and Behavioral Sciences (e.g., Journal of Comparative Policy Analysis).

B.2. Broader Impacts:

A. Network Development and Engagement: The SHCN brought together 8 Universities, 11 cities, 3 major utilities and multi-city organizations like ICLEI. International partnerships were also developed with cities and organizations in India. The research supported the work of 30+ faculty and 166+ associated students and postdocs, who were funded by the NSF SHCN. Collaborations have continued in the form of joint papers, future proposals, ongoing city collaborations, and a long-lived website (sustainablehealthycities.org) and data repository (globalcitydata.com).

B. Education and Training: The network formally conferred certificates to 31 students from all 8 SHC institutions, who completed a sequence of three SHC courses in graduate interdisciplinary urban sustainability training.

C. Research Outputs and Translation to Policy Briefs: >125 peer-reviewed papers and 49 conference papers were published. The key research papers were made accessible to lay audiences through policy briefs (two-page summary) publicly available on our website.

D. Public Engagement, Activity, and Reports: The network issued a public statement with the US American Heart Association, led a UNEP report on urban agriculture and food systems' potential to advance multiple sustainability goals, as well as prepared technical reports and policy briefs with the Twin cities and ICLEI.

E. Open-Source Databases: Multiple open-source data products are featured on an integrative web platform (globalcitiesdata.com).

F. Direct Policy Engagement: The network convened food systems planning in partnership with the city of Minneapolis as well as carbon mitigation pathway planning for the Twin-Cities region.
